## Objectives
:::{.center}
- Understand the basic logic behind comparing 2 groups
- Identify the usefulness of the independent t-test
- Identify the basic concepts of the independent t-test
- Conduct an independent t-test
- Interpret the results of an independent t-test
::::

:::


## That is all folks!
## Not exactly...
 
## We need to know:
  +  is the difference real?
  +  size of the difference?

# Conducting and interpreting

## Hands on exercises
### Get ready!

::: {.notes}
Download data from teams
:::

## Study
:::: {.columns}
::: {.column width="50%"}
Effect of ADHD on planning ability
:::

::: {.column width="50%"}
### Variables
- ADHD
    + healthy
    + ADHD
- Plannig: Standardized test
:::
::::

::: {.notes}
Standardized tests: mean? SD?
:::

## Hypothesis
- H0: No effect
- H1: Effect

::: {.notes}
- H0: Hardheaded
:::

## Info needed
:::: {.columns}
::: {.column width="50%"}
- Effect size
:::

::: {.column width="50%"}
- Statistical significance
:::
::::

::: {.notes}
What are these?
:::

## Viz
:::: {.columns}
::: {.column width="50%"}
- Bar plot
:::

::: {.column width="50%"}
- Box plot
:::
::::

::: {.notes}
- Which provides more info?

- Why use both? More info = better
:::

## Descriptive stats
- basic
- detailed
  
::: {.notes}
- group data
- detailed: mean, median, SD, Range
:::

# Conducting an independent t-test
![](./assets/conduct_ttest.png)

## Interpretation

## Effect size

## Unstandardized
- Mean difference
- 95% CI

::: {.notes}
Diff in raw scores?
:::

## Standardized

:::: {.columns}
::: {.column width="50%"}
### Indicators
- Hedges g
- 95% CI
::: 

::: {.column width="50%"}
### Interpretation
- small: .2 - 0.49
- medium: 0.5 - 0.79
- large: 0.8+
:::
::::

::: {.notes}
- Diff in terms of SD?
- Why Hedges?
:::

## Statistical significance
:::: {.columns}
::: {.column width="50%"}
### Where to look
- Equal variances not assumed
- Significance, two sided
:::

::: {.column width="50%"}
### Interpretation
- p-value < 0.05 = Statistical significant
- p-value > 0.05 = not statistical significant
:::
:::: 

# Assumptions
## Assumptions
- Types of variables (GLM)
- Normal distribution
- Homegeinity of variance (Welch's test) - not important
- No outliers

::: {.notes}
What are assumptions?
:::

# Closing

## Recap
- What analysis?
- Usefulness?
- Predictor type?
- Type of outcome?
- Pieces of info t-tests provide?
- Assumptions?

::: {.notes}
- t test
- compare means
- categorical
- numeric
- ES, stats sig
- var types, normal distribution, homo variances, outliers
:::

## Questions?

::: {.notes}
- What was easiest?
- What was hardest?
:::

include-after-body:
<script>
  // htmlwidgets need to know to resize themselves when slides are shown/hidden.
  // Fire the "slideenter" event (handled by htmlwidgets.js) when the current
  // slide changes (different for each slide format).
  (function () {
    function fireSlideChanged(previousSlide, currentSlide) {

      // dispatch for htmlwidgets
      const event = window.document.createEvent("Event");
      event.initEvent("slideenter", true, true);
      window.document.dispatchEvent(event);

      // dispatch for shiny
      if (window.jQuery) {
        if (previousSlide) {
          window.jQuery(previousSlide).trigger("hidden");
        }
        if (currentSlide) {
          window.jQuery(currentSlide).trigger("shown");
        }
      }
    }

    // hookup for reveal
    if (window.Reveal) {
      window.Reveal.addEventListener("slidechanged", function(event) {
        fireSlideChanged(event.previousSlide, event.currentSlide);
      });
    }

    // hookup for slidy
    if (window.w3c_slidy) {
      window.w3c_slidy.add_observer(function (slide_num) {
        // slide_num starts at position 1
        fireSlideChanged(null, w3c_slidy.slides[slide_num - 1]);
      });
    }

  })();
</script>
